title: Protein Complex Structure Analysis with YASARA
text:
The goal of this practical is to analyze protein-protein interactions using the classic model system of Barnase-Barstar from Bacillus amyloliquefaciens (PDB ID: 1BRS). This system represents an excellent example of protein-protein recognition and binding specificity.
Barnase is a small extracellular ribonuclease that degrades RNA. On its own, it‚Äôs toxic to the producing cell. Barstar is an intracellular protein inhibitor of Barnase that binds extremely tightly and blocks the RNase active site, protecting the bacterium until Barnase is secreted.
In this practical, we will prepare the crystal structure, analyze the protein-protein interface, and identify key interacting residues that are critical for complex formation.






REMEMBER: Create a working directory



# Create a new folder for this practical
mkdir -p ~/BIO512/AF
# All input and output files will be placed in this directory

# Also note that you need to download the materials from the Vera 
scp -r <your_vera_username>@vera2.chalmers.se:/cephyr/NOBACKUP/groups/n2bin_gu/BIO512/AF/* ~/BIO512/AF/








Learning Objectives



By the end you should be able to:

Prepare protein complex structures for analysis using YASARA
Visualize and analyze protein-protein interactions
Identify hydrogen bonds at protein interfaces
Determine key residues involved in protein-protein recognition
Understand the structural basis of protein binding specificity

title: Protein Complex Structure Analysis with YASARA
text:
2.1 Setting up YASARA workspace

Set the working directory (important):

Open YASARA
Options > Working directory > navigate and find the ‚ÄòAF‚Äô folder > OK

Download the crystal structure:

File > Load > PDB file from Internet > 1BRS
You can see three identical Barnase-Barstar complexes where we need only one

title: Protein Complex Structure Analysis with YASARA
text:
2.2 Understanding the structure contents

Analyze the scene contents: In the right-hand panel, you can see a single object named 1BRS. Click on it to expand. There are 12 molecules under 1BRS:

Mol A, B, C = Barnase (ribonuclease)
Mol D, E, F = Barstar (inhibitor)
Mol A, B, C, D, E, F (in red) = water molecules

title: Protein Complex Structure Analysis with YASARA
text:
2.3 Structure cleaning

Remove redundant molecules:

Remove water molecules (highlighted in red) by right-clicking and choosing ‚ÄúDelete‚Äù
Remove Mol B, C, E, F (right-click and choose ‚ÄúDelete‚Äù)
Now you have only one Barnase (Mol A)-Barstar (Mol D) complex

Center the structure:

Right-click on the object (1brs) from the right-hand panel and choose ‚ÄòCenter‚Äô

Add missing hydrogen atoms:

Edit > Clean > All

title: Protein Complex Structure Analysis with YASARA
text:
2.4 Force field and energy minimization

Select the force field:

Simulation > Force field > AMBER 14 > check the box next to ‚Äòuse PME‚Ä¶‚Äô > OK

Minimize the energy:

Options > Energy minimization

Clean up simulation cell:

From the right-hand panel, right-click on SimCell and Delete

Save the prepared complex:

File > Save as > PDB file > select 1BRS from both Sequence and Name panels > OK > give a name (1BRS_complex.pdb)

title: Protein Complex Structure Analysis with YASARA
text:
3.1 Visualization setup

Optimize visualization:

View > Hide atoms > Aliphatic hydrogens

title: Protein Complex Structure Analysis with YASARA
text:
3.2 Hydrogen bond analysis

Visualize protein-protein interactions:

Open the command window (press space bar on your keyboard)
Enter the command: ShowHBoAtom Mol A with distance<2.6 from Mol D
Alternative command: ShowHBoAtom Mol D with distance<2.6 from Mol A
You can now see hydrogen bonds between the two proteins shown as yellow dashed lines








Understanding the commands




ShowHBoAtom displays hydrogen bond atoms
distance<2.6 sets the maximum distance for hydrogen bond detection (2.6 √Ö)
Mol A refers to Barnase, Mol D refers to Barstar

title: Protein Complex Structure Analysis with YASARA
text:
3.3 Identifying key interactions

Analyze the binding interface:

Take a closer look at the interface between the two proteins
Focus on regions with multiple hydrogen bonds
Note the types of residues involved in the interactions

Identify critical residues: Examine which residues of Barstar (Mol D) form the most hydrogen bonds with Barnase (Mol A):

ASP39 of Barstar: Forms 4 strong hydrogen bonds with LYS27, ARG83, and ARG87 of Barnase
ASP35 of Barstar: Forms 2 hydrogen bonds with ARG59 and GLU60 of Barnase








Experimental validation



Experimental mutagenesis analysis shows that ASP39 and ASP35 are the key residues in the interaction. Mutations of these residues significantly disrupt complex formation.

title: Protein Complex Structure Analysis with YASARA
text:
3.4 Sequence preparation for further analysis

Obtain sequences for downstream analysis:

Open your internet browser and go to www.rcsb.org
Search for 1BRS
Click on ‚ÄòDownload Files‚Äô and choose ‚ÄòFASTA Sequence‚Äô
Open the downloaded FASTA file using a text editor (notepad on Windows)
You can see the sequences of both proteins that will be used in the next practical

title: Protein Complex Structure Analysis with YASARA
text:
4.1 Structural Analysis

How many hydrogen bonds do you observe at the Barnase-Barstar interface? Which regions show the highest density of interactions?
What types of amino acids are predominantly involved in the protein-protein interface? Are they mostly charged, polar, or hydrophobic?
Why do you think ASP39 and ASP35 are particularly important for binding? Consider their chemical properties and interaction partners.

title: Protein Complex Structure Analysis with YASARA
text:
4.2 Interface Characterization

Describe the shape complementarity between Barnase and Barstar. Is the interface flat or does it involve deep binding pockets?
What would you predict would happen if ASP39 was mutated to:

Alanine (A) - a small, nonpolar residue?
Arginine (R) - a positively charged residue?

From a biological perspective, why is tight binding between Barnase and Barstar essential for the bacterium?

title: Protein Complex Structure Analysis with YASARA
text:
4.3 Experimental Design

If you were to design experiments to test the importance of the identified residues, what mutations would you make and what assays would you perform?
Besides hydrogen bonds, what other types of interactions might be important at this interface? How could you analyze them?

title: Protein Complex Structure Analysis with YASARA
text:
5.1 Binding Specificity

Electrostatic complementarity: Negatively charged Asp residues in Barstar interact with positively charged Lys/Arg residues in Barnase
Shape complementarity: The proteins fit together like puzzle pieces
Multiple contact points: Several residues contribute to the overall binding affinity

title: Protein Complex Structure Analysis with YASARA
text:
5.2 Functional Implications

Active site blocking: Barstar binding prevents RNA access to Barnase active site
Regulatory mechanism: Tight binding allows controlled release of Barnase activity
Evolutionary optimization: The interface has evolved for maximum binding strength








Key Takeaways




Protein-protein interfaces involve multiple types of interactions working together
Hydrogen bonds can be visualized and analyzed using computational tools
Key residues often involve complementary charges and multiple contact points
Structural analysis provides insights into binding mechanisms and specificity
Crystal structures serve as valuable starting points for understanding protein function

title: Protein Complex Structure Analysis with YASARA
text:
5.3 Preparation for Next Practical
In the next practical, you will use AI-based structure prediction (AlphaFold3) to: - Predict the structure of the wild-type Barnase-Barstar complex - Model the effects of mutations on complex formation - Compare predicted structures with the crystal structure you analyzed today
The sequences you obtained in step 15 will be used as input for AlphaFold3 predictions.

title: AI-Based Protein Complex Prediction with AlphaFold3
text:
In this practical, we will apply AI-based protein complex structure prediction using AlphaFold3 (AF3). You will learn about the capabilities of AF3 in predicting protein complexes from wild-type sequences and the effects of mutations on complex formation.
Building on the previous practical where you analyzed the crystal structure of the Barnase-Barstar complex and identified key interacting residues (ASP39 and ASP35), you will now use AF3 to predict how mutations to these critical residues affect complex stability and formation.






Prerequisites




Completed analysis of 1BRS crystal structure from previous practical
FASTA sequences of Barnase and Barstar from PDB
Gmail account for AlphaFold server access









Learning Objectives



By the end you should be able to:

Use AlphaFold3 server for protein complex prediction
Interpret AF3 confidence metrics (pTM and ipTM)
Design and analyze mutational studies computationally
Compare predicted structures with experimental crystal structures
Understand limitations of AI-based structure prediction for mutations

title: AI-Based Protein Complex Prediction with AlphaFold3
text:
2.1 Preparing sequences
You should have obtained the FASTA sequences from the previous practical. If not:

Get the sequences:

Open www.rcsb.org and search for 1BRS
Click on ‚ÄòDownload Files‚Äô and choose ‚ÄòFASTA Sequence‚Äô
Open the downloaded FASTA file with a text editor
You‚Äôll see sequences for both Barnase and Barstar

title: AI-Based Protein Complex Prediction with AlphaFold3
text:
2.2 Wild-type complex prediction

Access AlphaFold3 server:

Navigate to https://alphafoldserver.com
Log in with your Gmail account

Submit wild-type prediction:

Enter the WT sequence of Barstar (first protein)
Add entity as ‚Äúprotein‚Äù
Enter the WT sequence of Barnase (second protein)
Add entity as ‚Äúprotein‚Äù
Click ‚ÄúContinue and preview job‚Äù
Give a name to the job: wtBarnase-wtBarstar
Submit the job








Processing time



AF3 jobs can take several hours to complete. You may need to check back later or use pre-computed results if available.



Download results:

Once completed, click on the job
Note the confidence metrics:

pTM (global metric): Confidence in individual protein structures
ipTM (interface metric): Confidence in protein-protein interface

Download results by clicking ‚ÄúDownload‚Äù
Rename the file to wtBarnase_wtBarstar.zip
Extract: unzip wtBarnase_wtBarstar.zip -d wtBarnase_wtBarstar

title: AI-Based Protein Complex Prediction with AlphaFold3
text:
3.1 Mutation to Alanine (conservative)

Prepare D39A-D35A mutant sequences:

Take the Barstar sequence from the FASTA file
Find position 39 (ASP/D) and replace with Alanine (A)
Find position 35 (ASP/D) and replace with Alanine (A)
Keep Barnase sequence unchanged

Submit D39A-D35A prediction:

Enter the mutated Barstar sequence
Enter the WT Barnase sequence
Job name: wtBarnase_D39A-D35ABarstar
Submit and download results when complete

title: AI-Based Protein Complex Prediction with AlphaFold3
text:
3.2 Mutation to Arginine (charge reversal)

Prepare D39R-D35R mutant sequences:

Take the Barstar sequence from the FASTA file
Find position 39 (ASP/D) and replace with Arginine (R)
Find position 35 (ASP/D) and replace with Arginine (R)
Keep Barnase sequence unchanged

Submit D39R-D35R prediction:

Enter the mutated Barstar sequence
Enter the WT Barnase sequence
Job name: wtBarnase_D39R-D35RBarstar
Submit and download results when complete

title: AI-Based Protein Complex Prediction with AlphaFold3
text:
4.1 Confidence metrics comparison

Compare AF3 confidence scores:




Complex
ipTM
pTM




WT
0.93
0.94


D39A-D35A
0.89
0.92


D39R-D35R
0.25
0.62









Interpreting metrics




pTM: Confidence in overall fold (0-1 scale, >0.8 is high confidence)
ipTM: Confidence in interface prediction (0-1 scale, >0.8 is high confidence)
Lower scores indicate less confidence in the predicted structure

title: AI-Based Protein Complex Prediction with AlphaFold3
text:
4.2 Structural comparison with crystal structure

Prepare YASARA for comparison:

Clean up YASARA screen: File > New > Yes
Open the prepared crystal structure: 1BRS_complex.pdb
Open the AF3 predicted WT structure: model_0.cif (from wtBarnase_wtBarstar folder)








AF3 output format



AF3 predicts 5 models (model_0 to model_4) where model_0 always has the highest-ranking confidence value.



Superpose predicted on crystal structure:

Analyze > Superpose > Objects
Select ‚Äúfold_wtbaranase‚Ä¶‚Äù (predicted structure) from Sequence panel > OK
Select ‚Äú1BRS_complex‚Ä¶‚Äù (crystal structure) from Sequence panel > OK
In ‚ÄúSet parameters‚Äù window: Uncheck all boxes except ‚ÄúResidue name‚Äù and ‚ÄúResidue number‚Äù > OK

Calculate RMSD for Barstar:

Analyze > RMSD of > Molecules
Choose ‚ÄúD‚Äù (Barstar of crystal structure) from Sequence panel > OK
Choose ‚ÄúA‚Äù (predicted Barstar) > OK > OK
RMSD value will be shown in the command window

Repeat for mutant structures:

Clean up YASARA screen and repeat steps 10-12 for both mutant predictions
Complete the RMSD comparison table:





Comparison Pair
RMSD (√Ö)




Crystal vs WT
2.76


Crystal vs D39A-D35A
2.90


Crystal vs D39R-D35R
9.42

title: AI-Based Protein Complex Prediction with AlphaFold3
text:
5.1 Understanding the results

Analysis of AF3 performance:

The results reveal important insights about AF3‚Äôs capabilities and limitations:

5.1.1 Alanine mutations (D39A-D35A):

Small decrease in confidence metrics (ipTM: 0.93‚Üí0.89)
Minimal structural change (RMSD: 2.76‚Üí2.90 √Ö)
AF3 prediction: Minor effect on complex formation
Experimental reality: These mutations drastically reduce binding affinity



5.1.2 Arginine mutations (D39R-D35R):

Dramatic decrease in confidence metrics (ipTM: 0.93‚Üí0.25)
Large structural deviation (RMSD: 2.76‚Üí9.42 √Ö)
AF3 prediction: Major disruption of complex formation
Experimental expectation: Strong electrostatic repulsion would indeed disrupt binding

title: AI-Based Protein Complex Prediction with AlphaFold3
text:
5.2 Critical analysis questions
Answer the following questions based on your results:

5.2.1 AF3 Performance Assessment

How well does AF3 predict the wild-type complex? Compare the confidence metrics and RMSD with the crystal structure.
What do the confidence metrics tell us about AF3‚Äôs certainty in its predictions for each variant?
Why might AF3 fail to capture the effect of alanine mutations but successfully predict the impact of arginine mutations?



5.2.2 Structural Biology Insights

From a chemical perspective, explain why:

D39A and D35A mutations might be more disruptive experimentally than AF3 predicts
D39R and D35R mutations show large effects in both experiments and AF3 predictions

What does this tell us about the different types of interactions that stabilize protein complexes?



5.2.3 Methodological Considerations

What are the limitations of using AF3 for mutational studies? When might it be reliable vs unreliable?
How could you validate these computational predictions experimentally?
What other computational approaches could complement AF3 for studying mutation effects?

title: AI-Based Protein Complex Prediction with AlphaFold3
text:
6.1 Detailed structural comparison

Analyze specific interface regions in detail
Compare hydrogen bonding patterns between structures
Examine conformational changes upon mutation

title: AI-Based Protein Complex Prediction with AlphaFold3
text:
6.2 Additional mutations

Predict effects of single mutations (D39A only, D35A only)
Test conservative mutations (D39E, D35E)
Explore mutations in Barnase instead of Barstar








Key Takeaways




AF3 excels at predicting wild-type protein complex structures with high confidence
Mutation effects are not always accurately captured, especially for subtle changes
Charge-reversal mutations (D‚ÜíR) are better predicted than loss-of-function mutations (D‚ÜíA)
Confidence metrics (pTM, ipTM) provide valuable information about prediction reliability
Experimental validation remains essential for understanding mutation effects
AI predictions should be interpreted alongside structural and chemical principles

title: AI-Based Protein Complex Prediction with AlphaFold3
text:
6.3 Biological Significance
This analysis demonstrates that:

Protein-protein interfaces rely on multiple, subtle interactions that may not be fully captured by current AI models
Electrostatic interactions are crucial for the Barnase-Barstar interface and are better predicted than hydrophobic or entropic effects
AF3 represents a powerful tool for structural biology but has limitations that must be understood
Computational and experimental approaches are complementary for understanding protein function

The Barnase-Barstar system serves as an excellent model for understanding both the capabilities and limitations of AI-based structure prediction in the context of protein evolution and design.

title: Peptide Classification with Machine Learning
text:
Protein‚Äìprotein interactions (PPIs) are central to almost every biological process, yet their complexity often makes them difficult to describe and predict. Traditional models emphasize short-range atomic contacts or electrostatic complementarity, but these approaches can fail to capture the broader physicochemical principles that govern biomolecular recognition.
In the paper ‚ÄúDeciphering peptide‚Äìprotein interactions via composition-based prediction: a case study with survivin/BIRC5‚Äù (Anindya et al., 2024), a different approach was introduced. Instead of focusing on the detailed three-dimensional structures of proteins, the study analyzed their composition (the number and types of atoms or functional groups within peptides) and used this as a predictive descriptor of interaction with the human protein survivin (BIRC5)
The goal of this practical is to build a classifier that predicts peptide binding signal from microarray data using encoded features derived from amino-acid properties. You will first perform a basic run-through of the provided notebook, then complete a set of ML-focused tasks.
Use the annotated notebook aa_scan2_clean_annotated.ipynb for the exercise.






Create a working directory



# Create a new folder for this practical
mkdir -p ~/BIO512/ML_lab

# Fetch the required files from Vera
# do note that <__> is a placeholder for your vera username
scp -r <your_vera_username>@vera2.chalmers.se:/cephyr/NOBACKUP/groups/n2bin_gu/BIO512/practicals/Peptide_Classification/* ~/BIO512/Peptide_Classification/








Learning Objectives



By the end you should be able to:

Encode peptide sequences into feature vectors using an AA property table
Compare classifiers with cross validation using robust metrics
Interpret influential features in biochemical terms
Report reproducible results with seeds, versions, and parameters

title: Peptide Classification with Machine Learning
text:
3.1 1. Imports

Import core libraries. If an import fails, install and re-run.

import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pylab as plt
import numpy as np

title: Peptide Classification with Machine Learning
text:
3.2 2. Load the encoding table

Load aa_properties.xlsx and confirm it contains the AA letter column (e.g., aa) and feature columns.

#Positionwise carbon (C-Pos)
df=pd.read_excel("aa_properties.xlsx")
# H-wise Carbon (C-Coord)
#df=pd.read_excel("aa_properties2.xlsx")
# identity (AA-Letter)
#df=pd.read_excel("aa_properties3.xlsx")
df

title: Peptide Classification with Machine Learning
Peptide Classification with Machine Learning
text:
3.4 4. Load microarray data

Load the microarray dataset (Clean_results_2_2019.xlsx).

pf=pd.read_excel("Clean_results_2_2019.xlsx")
pf

title: Peptide Classification with Machine Learning
text:
3.5 5. Apply encoding

Map peptrans over the peptide sequence to produce feature vectors.

transpf=pf['Peptide'].apply(peptrans)
transpf

title: Peptide Classification with Machine Learning
section: 3.6 6. Merge feature vectors with original data
text:
3.6 6. Merge feature vectors with original data

Concatenate features with the original dataframe.

mergepf = pd.concat([pf, transpf], axis=1, sort=False)
mergepf

title: Peptide Classification with Machine Learning
text:
3.7 7. Tidy metadata and target

Create Prot_pep and Prot_res_pep for better metadata
Set index to Prot_res_pep so that we use the most informative descriptor
Rename target Survivin label to Fluorescence.

mergepf["Prot_pep"] = mergepf["Protein"].map(str) +"_"+ mergepf["Peptide"]
mergepf["Prot_res_pep"] = mergepf["Protein"].map(str) +"_"+ mergepf["Residue number"].map(str)+"_"+ mergepf["Peptide"]
mergepf=mergepf.set_index('Prot_res_pep')
mergepf=mergepf.rename(columns={u'Survivin, 1 ¬µg/ml': u'Fluorescence'})
mergepf

title: Peptide Classification with Machine Learning
text:
3.8 8. Baseline model
The main engine block of the notebook has multiple configurations of various classifiers prepared. These classifiers all come as part of the scikit-learn library. To use a different classifier, simply uncomment the relevant line and comment out the rest.

Use the default MLPClassifier block from the notebook to build a baseline.

from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier, AdaBoostClassifier
from sklearn.neighbors import KNeighborsClassifier
from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeClassifier
from sklearn.neural_network import MLPClassifier
from sklearn.gaussian_process import GaussianProcessClassifier
from sklearn.gaussian_process.kernels import RBF
from sklearn import datasets, svm, metrics
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler, MinMaxScaler
#clf = svm.SVC(gamma=0.001)
#clf = RandomForestClassifier(max_depth=None, n_estimators=100, max_features='auto')
#clf = MLPClassifier(solver='lbfgs',random_state=1, max_iter=10000)
clf = MLPClassifier(hidden_layer_sizes=(2,), random_state=1, max_iter=10000)
#clf = GaussianProcessClassifier(1.0 * RBF(1.0))
#clf = DecisionTreeClassifier(max_depth=5)
#clf = KNeighborsClassifier(5)
#clf = AdaBoostClassifier()

feature_names=[u'CA-Gly', u'Pro-MC', u'CB', u'CB-Pro',
        u'Carboxyl', u'Amide',
        u'His', u'Trp', u'Phe-Tyr', u'OH-Tyr', u'CG', u'CD', u'CE',
        u'OH', u'SH', u'S', u'NH3', u'Arg',u'MC']
X = np.array(mergepf[feature_names])

# Other array setups #

Y=np.array(mergepf[u'Fluorescence']>0)

# Other array setups #

sc=StandardScaler()

X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(
    X, Y, test_size=0.5, shuffle=True)

X_train = sc.fit_transform(X_train)
X_test = sc.transform(X_test)

clf.fit(X_train, y_train)
predict=clf.predict(X_test)
predict

title: Peptide Classification with Machine Learning
text:
3.9 9. Diagnostics

Plot the confusion matrix and print the classification report.

from sklearn.metrics import ConfusionMatrixDisplay
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

disp = ConfusionMatrixDisplay.from_estimator(
    clf, X_test, y_test, cmap='Blues'
)
disp.ax_.set_title("Confusion Matrix")

print("Confusion matrix:\n", disp.confusion_matrix)
plt.show()
print(f"Classification report for classifier {clf}:\n"
      f"{metrics.classification_report(y_test, predict)}\n")






Recommended improvements for later tasks




Prefer stratified splits and wrap scaling + model in a Pipeline to avoid leakage.
Use macro F1, balanced accuracy, and PR curves when classes are imbalanced.

title: Data Grouping and Visualization
text: This companion to the DeSeq practical focuses on grouping, advanced PCA using DE-only genes, and sample correlation heatmaps. We will continue in the same notebook as last time, so no need to make a new workspace.

title: Data Grouping and Visualization
text:
2.1 Questions

Q12: Do you see any improvement in the separation of the Normal and Infected group? What variable(s) that you observe?
Q13: Explain what is ‚Äúloading‚Äù in PCA. Identify top-loading (best performing features) separating Normal and Infected groups. (hint: https://erdogant.github.io/pca/pages/html/Algorithm.html#loadings)

title: Data Grouping and Visualization
text:
3.1 Steps

Calculate the sample correlations using ‚Äú.corr()‚Äù functions from pandas. Remember that we want to calculate the distance between samples rather than among genes.







Tip



Suggestion: use the count_PCA variable instead of count
https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.corr.html


corr = {__}

Use sns.clustermap() to plot your correlation matrix







Tip



Suggestion: use ‚Äúcmap = ‚ÄòRdYlBu‚Äô‚Äù to have better color map


sns.clustermap({__})

title: Data Grouping and Visualization
text:
3.2 Questions:

Q14: What do you conclude from the clustering, do the PCA and the heatmap reflect eachother? Are there any sample outliers?
Q15: Can you identify which correlation method that you use?

title: n2bin: Connecting to the HPC
text:
1 Introduction
This tutorial is to take you through the final steps of setting up and accessing the c3se High Performance Computing infrastructure. The specific cluster we will use is called Vera. You will be introduced to this cluster in the lecture and here you can find more information about it, including what resources that are available, how to run jobs and other documentation.
We will walk you through step by step in this tutorial so that we (hopefully) can assist if there are any problems.






Pre-course setup



To be able to follow these steps you first have to have followed the steps of the Pre-course Setup including registration at SUPR and application to the course HPC project.





2 Setting up a Chalmers ID - IF you have the option to do so in the login portal - else continue to next step

Navigate to https://myaccount.chalmers.se/.
Log in with your GU account.
Choose ‚ÄúActivate CID‚Äù and follow the instructions to activate your account







Remember your password!



The CID username and password are the ones you will use to log in to the cluster





3 Adding Vera/c3se at SUPR

Log in to SUPR
Click ‚ÄúAccounts‚Äù in the left side menu
Request access to Vera/c3se







Proceed even without a CID



If you don‚Äôt have that option in the CID portal you should apply for Vera access in SUPR anyway. They will then assign you a CID that you can access and create a PW for in the CID portal when you have received an email notification about this.





4 Setting up Chalmers VPN (if you don‚Äôt already have a GU VPN)
To be able to access c3se from other networks than in GU or Chalmers, you will need a Chalmers VPN

Navigate to https://chalmers.topdesk.net/tas/public/ssp/content/detail/knowledgeitem?unid=07e6154089a648d09711ccc42a42fc88
Follow the instructions to set up the Chalmers VPN




5 Connecting to the HPC using ssh in VSCode
To be able to connect to the HPC in a manner that will let you use the full suite of tools available (or most of them at least) in VSCode, you will need to install the Remote - SSH extension.

Open VSCode
Go to the Extensions view by clicking on the Extensions icon in the Activity Bar on the side of the window or by pressing Ctrl+Shift+X
Search for ‚ÄúRemote - SSH‚Äù and install the extension by Microsoft (if youre unsure how install extensions, see here)
After installation, you will see a new icon in the Activity Bar on the side of the window. Click on it to open the Remote Explorer view.

If the SSH Targets are not visible, click on the drop down to expand the view

Click on the + (‚ÄúNew Remote‚Äù) icon next to SSH header to add a new SSH host
In the input box that appears, enter the SSH connection string for Vera: <your_chalmers_id>@vera1.c3se.chalmers.se (replace <your_chalmers_id> with your actual Chalmers ID)
Press Enter to confirm
You will be prompted to select the SSH configuration file to update. Choose the default option (usually ~/.ssh/config)

Once you have added the SSH host, you can connect to Vera:

In the Remote Explorer view, find the Vera entry under SSH Targets (or by clicking on the blue ‚Äúremote window‚Äù icon in the bottom left corner of VSCode)

Click on the ‚ÄúConnect to Host‚Äù icon (an arrow if you want the same window, square if you want a new one) next to the Vera entry
If you clicked on the blue ‚Äúremote window‚Äù icon, select ‚ÄúRemote-SSH: Connect to Host‚Ä¶‚Äù and then select the Vera entry

A new VSCode window will open, and you will be prompted to enter your Chalmers ID password
After entering your password, you should be connected to Vera, and you can start working on the HPC cluster directly from VSCode. Make sure that you open your home folder on Vera to open up a workspace.
You can verify that you are connected to Vera by opening a new terminal in VSCode (Terminal > New Terminal) and checking the hostname in the terminal prompt. It should show something like your_chalmers_id@vera:~$

title: Pre-course setup
text:
Here is a tutorial to guide you through how to set up your computers for the BIO511 and following courses. Throughout the course we will both teach you how to use your local computer for bioinformatics but also, for more heavy duty stuff, use the c3se high performance computing cluster (HPC). The setup will therefore prepare you for both cases.
Some of you might already have done some kinds of bioinformatics and have other setups and if you are comfortable with those, that‚Äôs fine by us. We will however not be able to give support/trouble shoot different kinds of setups so we ask you to make sure you have what‚Äôs below as a minimum.

title: Pre-course setup
text:
Here is a tutorial to guide you through how to set up your computers for the BIO511 and following courses. Throughout the course we will both teach you how to use your local computer for bioinformatics but also, for more heavy duty stuff, use the c3se high performance computing cluster (HPC). The setup will therefore prepare you for both cases.
Some of you might already have done some kinds of bioinformatics and have other setups and if you are comfortable with those, that‚Äôs fine by us. We will however not be able to give support/trouble shoot different kinds of setups so we ask you to make sure you have what‚Äôs below as a minimum.

title: Pre-course setup
text:
2 Setup for Mac / Linux users
macOS is Unix-based (specifically, it‚Äôs a certified Unix system built on BSD) and therefore one can run many Linux-compatible tools without modification directly. You can basically just use the built in Terminal app and start coding. The Terminal runs the zsh shell by default.
However, to get a better user experience, especially when we further on are going to access the HPC we will recommend using the integrated development environment (IDE) Visual Studio Code (VS Code). Please follow these instructions to do so.

title: Pre-course setup
text:
3 Setup for Windows users
Using a Windows computer for bioinformatic work has sadly not been ideal most of the time, but large advances in recent years have made this quite feasible through the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL).
Apart from the Linux kernel provided by WSL, we also recommend installing the integrated development environment (IDE) Visual Studio Code (VS Code), and the tutorial will guide you through how to set up WSL integrated in VS Code. If you already feel comfortable with another IDE such and PyCharm since before, that‚Äôs ok but we may not be able to trouble shoot your setup during the course.
There are two substantially different versions of the Linux subsystem, WSL1 and WSL2. We strongly recommend using WSL2, which offers an essentially complete Linux experience and better performance.
Using the Linux subsystem will give you access to a full command-line bash shell and a Linux implementation on your Windows 10 or 11 PC. For the difference between the Linux Bash Shell and the Windows PowerShell, see e.g. this article.
The installation has three main steps:

Install WSL2 on Windows 10 or 11, follow the instructions here: Installing the Windows Subsystem and the Linux Bash







Note



If you run into error messages when trying to download files through the Linux shell (e.g. curl:(6) Could not resolve host) then try adding the Google name server to the internet configuration by running sudo nano /etc/resolv.conf then add nameserver 8.8.8.8 to the bottom of the file and save it.








Caution



Whenever a setup instruction specifies Mac or Linux (i.e. only those two, with no alternative for Windows), please follow the Linux instructions.



Install Visual Studio Code on the Windows side (not in WSL).







Note



Note: When prompted to Select Additional Tasks during installation, be sure to check the Add to PATH option so you can easily open a folder in WSL using the code command.



Install the WSL extension. If you plan to work with other remote extensions in VS Code, you may choose to install the Remote Development extension pack.

title: Pre-course setup
section: 4 Getting access to the High Performance computing cluster c3se
text:
4 Getting access to the High Performance computing cluster c3se
Now you have your local computer setup for bioinformatics. However, for many of the practicals we will use a high performance computing cluster, both so that you get familiar with that way of working, to keep a more controlled environment for you in the beginning and to let you perform analyses that require a bit more heavy duty computing power than your local machines.
This setup will be the same regardless of your OS.

Register yourself at SUPR. SUPR is the database for the National Swedish Infrastructure for Supercomputing (NAISS) and SUPR is used to keep track of persons, projects, project proposals and more. Please register with Federated Identity using your GU email address.
When you have registered, please send an email to kaisa.thorell@gu.se and I will add you to the c3se project.

title: Differential Expression and Enrichment Analysis
text:
In this practical, you will perform differential expression analysis using PyDESeq2, explore the data structure with PCA, and interpret results via GO Biological Process enrichment. You will work from the count data we generated in the previous practical, but double check that it matches the data provided. If it doesnt match or you dont have it, you can use the provided counts.tsv.
Ensure these files are in your working directory before starting the analysis (some need to be copied in).

Count matrix: counts.tsv (from the previous segment)
Sample metadata: metadata.txt







Setup Instructions



mkdir -p ~/BIO512/DESeq_lab
cd ~/BIO512/DESeq_lab

# Required files can be fetched from the Cluster
scp -r <your_vera_username>@vera2.chalmers.se:/cephyr/NOBACKUP/groups/n2bin_gu/BIO512/practicals/DeSeq/* ~/BIO512/DESeq_lab
cd ~/BIO512/DESeq_lab

# Build the conda environment needed from the provided environment file
conda env create --file="./env/env.yml"

conda activate BIO512_v1

ipython kernel install --user --name=BIO512_v1

# Launch Jupyter Lab or run the notebook in VScode

# For any excersise that has a {__}, this is a placeholder that you need to fill in with appropriate code.
myvariable = {__}
# should be replaced with actual code.
myvariable = "Hello, World!"

title: Differential Expression and Enrichment Analysis
text:
3.1 Steps

Let‚Äôs use the 2nd initialization method, limiting the PCs to 3

model = pca(n_components={__})

Setting up the dataframe for analysis

Remove the all zero genes from our count file, by keeping only the rows with total sum greater than 0. Assign it to ‚Äúcount_PCA‚Äù.
Replace the sample ID to their conditions (normal or infected) (Tips: we make sure that the sample sequence in the count file is the same with metadata)

Hint: A pythonic way to do this count_PCA = count_PCA.rename(columns = metadata["Conditions"])

Log-transform the count_PCA. Read about ‚Äúlog1p‚Äù function from numpy, what does it mean?


# Setting up the dataframe for analysis
## 1. Remove the all zero genes from our count file, by keeping only the rows with total sum greater than 0. Assign it to "count_PCA".
count_PCA = count[{__}]

## 2. Replace the sample ID to their conditions (normal or infected)
### 2.1. we make sure that the sample sequence in the count file is the same with metadata (Yes it is in this example, but it is not going to always be like that :D)
count_PCA = count_PCA[metadata.index]

### 2.2. replacing the column names with their metadata["Conditions"] column
count_PCA.columns = {__}


## 3. Log-transform the count_PCA. Read about "log1p" function from numpy, what does it mean?
count_PCA = {__}

Perform the PCA analysis, on logged data using model.fit_transform() function (Note: This package requires gene names as the column names and the sample ID as the row names, so we have to transpose our dataframe (.T in the end))

results = model.{__}

Plot the PCA analysis with a scatter plot (Note: figsize option is to limit the dimension of the plot. Can be adjusted to fit your preference. Play around with it.)

fig, ax = {__}

title: Differential Expression and Enrichment Analysis
text:
3.2 Questions:

Q2: What is your interpretation of the PCA analysis? Is there any outliers? Justify your opinion.
Q3: Is the plot title total variant same as the PC1 + PC2 explained variant? If not, why?







PCA Cheatsheet:




model.scatter3d() ‚Äì> 3D PCA plotting
model.biplot() ‚Äì> Plotting top loading factors (model.biplot3d for 3D PCA)
Explore ‚Äúmodel.results‚Äù for detailed information of the PCA model, including ‚Äúexplained_var‚Äù, ‚Äúvariance_ratio‚Äù, ‚Äúloadings‚Äù, etc

More info: https://erdogant.github.io/pca/pages/html/index.html

title: Differential Expression and Enrichment Analysis
text:
4.1 Steps:

Create dds object. Use the original unfiltered count and metadata variables. For the design option, let‚Äôs use the ‚ÄúConditions‚Äù column on metadata

dds = DeseqDataSet(
    counts=count.T,
    metadata=metadata,
    design="~Conditions",
    refit_cooks=True,
)

Perform the DESeq2 analysis with deseq2() function on the dds object (It may take a few mins)

dds.deseq2()
OPTIONAL: Look at the sub-variables inside the dds object

Perform the comparison between Infected and Normal group using DeseqStats() function

ds = DeseqStats(dds, contrast=["Conditions", "Infected", "Normal"])

Retrieve the results and assign it to a different object, e.g.¬†deseq_results (hint: ds.results_df after running ds.summary()).

Remember that since we are doing a lot of tests, as many tests as genes in our experiment, we need to correct our pvalues. DESeq already did this while testing for differences among our groups, so let‚Äôs create a histogram of these adjusted pvalues and an MA-plot to inspect if there is any enrichment of DE genes.
ds.summary()
deseq_results = ds.results_df

Make a histogram using the hist() function on the padj column of the results object. Change arguments in the placeholder to make a nice histogram (eg. add some color, a title etc.) https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.hist.html

deseq_results["padj"].hist(bins = 100, {__})

Create a MA-plot with the plot_MA() function from DeseqStats object (not dds!).

ds.plot_MA()

Let‚Äôs remove the genes with NAN adjusted p-values. Use the .notna() function on the padj column of the results object to keep those that has valid adjusted p-values.







Tip



https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.notna.html
There are genes that have very low counts across all the samples, these can‚Äôt be tested for DE so they end up with an NA p-adj. Let‚Äôs remove them. Use the isna() function on the padj column of the results object. This will test if the padj is NA.
There should be 953 valid genes.


notna_deseq = {__}
notna_deseq.shape

title: Differential Expression and Enrichment Analysis
text:
4.2 Questions:

Q4: How many significantly differentially expressed genes in this comparison? (padj < 0.05)
Q5: What does the histogram tell you? Looking at the MA plot, approximately what are your highest and lowest Foldchanges?
Q6: How many genes with a p-adjusted value of NA did you have?
Q7: What is the top 5 most significantly differentially expressed genes based on their log2FoldChange? (padj < 0.05)Look for their gene names using online tools (e.g.¬†ENSG00000166211 is SPIC).







Tip



Remember: There are up and down-regulated genes, make sure that you sort it based on their absolute values. Hint: .sort_values(‚Äúlog2FoldChange‚Äù, key = abs)


notna_deseq[notna_deseq["padj"] < 0.05].sort_values("log2FoldChange", key = abs)






Note



Save the normalized count from DESeq2 and final result without the NAs as a tab-separated file
include the non-significant genes too. We will use this in our future lab on network and visualization.


notna_deseq[notna_deseq["padj"] < 0.05].to_csv("Deseq2_Results.txt", sep = "\t")
pd.DataFrame(dds.layers["normed_counts"], columns = dds.var_names, index=dds.obs_names).T.to_csv("Deseq2_NormalizedCount.txt", sep = "\t")

title: Differential Expression and Enrichment Analysis
text:
5.1 Steps

Since our the gene names are using ‚ÄúEnsembl Gene ID‚Äù and most enrichment analysis packages supports only ‚ÄúGene Name‚Äù or ‚ÄúHGNC ID‚Äù, let‚Äôs first convert them. We will use the pyBioMart package to help us retrieving the mapping file.







Tip



https://jrderuiter.github.io/pybiomart/api.html
NOTE: Gseapy package has similar functions, but pyBioMart package can give a more flexible implementation option in larger data


# Starting connections to ensembl website using the "Dataset" function from pyBioMart
dataset = Dataset(name='hsapiens_gene_ensembl', host='http://www.ensembl.org')

# Retrieving name mapping dataframe between "Esembl ID" and External Gene Name (HGNC)
mapping = dataset.query(attributes=['ensembl_gene_id', 'external_gene_name'])

#Look at the mapping structure
mapping.head()
# Let's copy the deseq results again, focusing only on differentially expressed genes
significant_deseq = deseq_results[deseq_results["padj"] < 0.05]

# Now we are merging the mapping dataframe to the significant_deseq object. read more on Pandas Merging function if needed
significant_deseq = significant_deseq.merge(mapping, left_index = True, right_on = "Gene stable ID")

#Let√§s remove those with no gene names
significant_deseq = significant_deseq[significant_deseq["Gene name"].notna()]

#Look at the new significant_deseq structure
significant_deseq.head()

# Now we have "Gene Name" columns that we can use for enrichment analysis

Make two lists of significantly differentially expressed genes (signficant_deseq object): up and down-regulated genes (use the Gene name columns)


up-regulated: Log2FoldChange > 0 (and padj < 0.05) ‚Äì> 80 genes
down-regulated: Log2FoldChange < 0 (and padj < 0.05) ‚Äì> 66 genes







Tip



hint: use .to_list() function to convert pandas series to list.
https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.Series.to_list.html


up = {__}
down = {__}
len(up)
len(down)

Perform enrichment analysis using Enrichr API from GSEAPY. Do one enrichment analysis for each direction (one for up and one for down-regulated genes). For uniformity, please use the object name enr_up and enr_down.







Tip



https://gseapy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/gseapy_example.html#Enrichr-Web-Serives-(without-a-backgound-input)


enr_up = {__}
enr_down = {__}

To get detailed output of the enrichment analysis results in dataframe format, access the .res2d variable under enr_up and enr_down

enr_up.res2d.head()
enr_down.res2d.head()

Plot the enrichment analysis results focusing on the top 10 most enriched processes for each up and down-regulated genes. Explore all the plotting options and pretify it with the options. (use the option cutoff=1, since we do not have that many genes to enrich)







Tip



https://gseapy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/gseapy_example.html#Plotting


ax = {__}
ax = {__}

title: Differential Expression and Enrichment Analysis
text:
5.2 Questions:

Q8: How many significantly enriched processes for up- and down-regulated genes? (Adjusted P-value < 0.11, arbitrary cut off)
Q9: What does ‚ÄúCombined Score‚Äù mean? Check https://maayanlab.cloud/Enrichr/help#basics
Q10: What are the genes associated with the process with the highest combined score in each direction?
Q11: What are the top 10 enriched processes for the up- and down-regulated genes? Include a figure for each direction.








Things to append to your submission




Save your notebook as PRACTICAL_DESEQ_ANALYSIS_yourname.ipynb
Add answers to the questions in separate markdown cells
Add your code blocks from the jupyter notebook with completed code where the placeholders were
Include some output cells with figures (if multiple runs are needed, keep only the last one)

title: Gene Co-Expression Network Analysis
text:
In this practical, we will construct (or load) a gene co-expression network from normalized RNA-seq counts and analyze its topology. You will compute centrality measures, detect modules via Leiden clustering, and perform functional enrichment on selected clusters.






Setup Instructions



mkdir -p ~/BIO512/Network_analysis
cd ~/BIO512/Network_analysis

# Required files can be fetched from the Cluster
scp -r <your_vera_username>@vera2.chalmers.se:/cephyr/NOBACKUP/groups/n2bin_gu/BIO512/Network_analysis/* ~/BIO512/Network_analysis/

# Remember to activate the conda environment
conda activate BIO512_v1
# Launch Jupyter Lab or run the notebook in VScode

# For any excersise that has a {__}, this is a placeholder that you need to fill in with appropriate code.
myvariable = {__}
# should be replaced with actual code.
myvariable = "Hello, World!"

title: Gene Co-Expression Network Analysis
text:
3.1 Questions

Q1: How many nodes and edges?
Q2: Network diameter and density? Interpret their meaning.

g.vcount()
g.ecount()
g.diameter()
g.density()

title: Gene Co-Expression Network Analysis
text:
4.1 Questions






Tip



Hint 1: The output of centrality measures in iGraph Python are lists. To convert to Pandas Series for easy analysis, use pd.Series(list, index = g.vs["name"])
Hint 2: Use the Pandas sort_values function to rank the Series https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.sort_values.html



Q3: Which genes are hubs (high degree centrality)? (top 10)

Q4: Which genes act as bridges between modules (high betweenness)? (top 10)

Q5: Perform Closeness and Eigenvector centrality analysis. Looking at top 40 most central genes for each measurement, is there any intersection between different methods? Which methods are more similar? Why?

Q6: Compare biological functions of hub vs.¬†bridge genes ‚Äî do they play different roles? (Hint: Use the Enrichr website or GSEAPY module from DESeq2 lab to identify their functions) https://maayanlab.cloud/Enrichr/

# Calculate centrality measures
degree_centrality = {__}
betweenness_centrality = {__}
closeness_centrality = {__}
eigenvector_centrality = {__}

# Add centrality values as node attributes
g.vs["degree"] = degree_centrality
g.vs["betweenness"] = betweenness_centrality
g.vs["closeness"] = closeness_centrality
g.vs["eigenvector"] = eigenvector_centrality

# Create a DF to present different centrality analyses
centrality_df = pd.DataFrame({
    "gene": g.vs["name"],
    "degree": degree_centrality,
    "betweenness": betweenness_centrality,
    "closeness": closeness_centrality,
    "eigenvector": eigenvector_centrality
})

title: Gene Co-Expression Network Analysis
section: 4.2 Optional: Advance Plotting: Use centrality variables as the node size
text:
4.2 Optional: Advance Plotting: Use centrality variables as the node size
fig, ax = plt.subplots() ## We are using matplotlib for the visualization, otherwise there are many other requirements to install
ig.plot(
    g,
    layout = layout,
    target=ax, # this option is to attach the plot to matplotlib
    vertex_size=g.degree(),
)

fig.set_size_inches(20, 20) # defining the size of the canvas

title: Gene Co-Expression Network Analysis
text:
5.1 Questions to Explore

Q7: How many modules/clusters can you detect in the network?
Q8: Which module is the largest? Which is the smallest?
Q9: Which modules contain the most hub genes identified earlier?
Q10: If you pick the largest module, what biological function might it represent? Make a visualization of top 10 most enriched processes







Tip



Use the Enrichr website or GSEAPY module from DESeq2 lab to identify their functions: https://maayanlab.cloud/Enrichr/**



Q11(OPTIONAL): Can you identify the hub gene(s) in the two biggest modules?







Tip



Slice the original network using .subgraph

title: Gene Co-Expression Network Analysis
section: 6.1 Optional Task: Can you identify the clusters with hubs using the plot?
text:
6.1 Optional Task: Can you identify the clusters with hubs using the plot?
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ig.plot(
    clustering,
    target=ax,
    layout=layout,
    mark_groups=True,
    #vertex_size=15,
    vertex_size=g.degree(),
)
fig.set_size_inches(20, 20)

title: Gene Co-Expression Network Analysis
text:
7.1 Load normalized count file
In generating gene co-expression network, we use normalized count instead of raw counts. It can be TPM, FPKM, RPKM, or any normalization. For this lab, we are going to use normalized count from the DESeq lab.
norm_count = pd.read_csv("Deseq2_NormalizedCount.txt", sep = "\t", index_col = 0)

# Exclude all-zero genes 
norm_count = norm_count[norm_count.sum(1) > 0]

title: Gene Co-Expression Network Analysis
text:
7.2 Generating Gene Co-Expression Network
def coexpression_generation(norm_count,padj_thr=0.05):
    print('Calculating Correlation..')
    temp=spearmanr(norm_count.T)
    corr=pd.DataFrame(temp[0],columns=list(norm_count.index),index=list(norm_count.index))
    pval=pd.DataFrame(temp[1],columns=list(norm_count.index),index=list(norm_count.index))
    print('Filtering the matrix Correlation..')
    corr=corr.where(np.triu(np.ones(corr.shape)).astype(np.bool))
    pval=pval.where(np.triu(np.ones(pval.shape)).astype(np.bool))
    print('Making long table of Correlation..')
    corr2=corr.unstack().reset_index(name='weight')
    pval2=pval.unstack().reset_index(name='pval')
    res=corr2.merge(pval2,on=['level_0','level_1'])
    res=res[res['level_0'] != res['level_1']]
    res=res.dropna()
    print('Adjusting P-val')
    res['padj']=multipletests(res['pval'],method='fdr_bh')[1]
    res=res[res.padj < padj_thr].reset_index(drop=True)
    res=res[['level_0','level_1','weight']]
    print('Done!!')
    return res

coexp_network = coexpression_generation(norm_count)
coexp_network = coexp_network[coexp_network["weight"] > 0]
coexp_network.to_csv("coexpression_network.txt", sep = "\t", index = False)
Map to gene names (optional):
# Starting connections to ensembl website using the "Dataset" function from pyBioMart
dataset = Dataset(name='hsapiens_gene_ensembl', host='http://www.ensembl.org')

# Retrieving name mapping dataframe between "Esembl ID" and External Gene Name (HGNC) and focusing only on "protein coding" genes
mapping = dataset.query(attributes=['ensembl_gene_id', 'external_gene_name'])
coexp_network.replace(mapping.set_index("Gene stable ID")["Gene name"]).dropna().to_csv("coexpression_network.txt", sep = "\t", index = False)






Note



The output is a dataframe with 3 columns:

level_1: gene node 1
level_2: gene node 2
weight: correlation score

title: Molecular Docking Analysis
text:
The goal of this practical is to understand how molecular glue stabilizes protein-protein interactions. We will work with FKBP12 ‚Äì a small cytosolic immunophilin and the FRB domain of mTOR. Rapamycin acts as the bridge that ‚Äúglues‚Äù them together, forming a stable FKBP12/rapamycin/FRB ternary complex. When this complex forms, mTOR signaling is reduced, cells decrease anabolic programs (e.g., protein synthesis and growth), slow or arrest the cell cycle, and often increase autophagy.
In this practical, we will perform molecular docking to dock the molecular glue in the interface of two proteins and compare the docking result with the co-crystallized pose.






Create a new working directory



# Create a new folder for this practical
# ex.
mkdir -p ~/BIO512/MD_practicals
# All input and output files will be placed in this directory

# Also note that you need to download the materials from the Vera 
scp -r <your_vera_username>@vera2.chalmers.se:/cephyr/NOBACKUP/groups/n2bin_gu/BIO512/MD_practicals/* ~/BIO512/MD_practicals/








Learning Objectives



By the end you should be able to:

Prepare protein structures for molecular docking using YASARA
Perform protein-ligand docking simulations
Analyze docking results and binding energies
Compare predicted poses with crystal structures using RMSD calculations
Evaluate the success of docking predictions

title: Molecular Docking Analysis
text:
2.1 Setting up YASARA workspace

Set the working directory (important):

Open YASARA
Options > Working directory > navigate and find the ‚ÄòDocking‚Äô folder > OK

Download the structure:

File > Load > PDB file from Internet > 3FAP

title: Molecular Docking Analysis
text:
2.2 Understanding the structure
In the right-hand panel, you can see 3FAP. Click on it to expand it. There are five molecules under 3FAP:

Mol A = chain A of the protein
Mol B = chain B of the protein

Mol A = ligand (rapamycin)
Mol A (in red) = water molecules of chain A
Mol B (in red) = water molecules of chain B

title: Molecular Docking Analysis
text:
2.3 Structure cleaning and preparation

Remove water molecules:

From the right-hand panel, right-click on both water entries and click ‚ÄòDelete‚Äô

Add missing hydrogen atoms:

Edit > Clean > All

Minimize the energy of the system:

Options > Choose Experiment > Energy minimization








Troubleshooting



On Linux, you may need to pause the minimization and continue to make it work: Options > Control experiment > Pause/Continue



Delete SimCell:

From the right-hand panel, right-click on SimCell and Delete

Save the prepared complex:

File > Save as > PDB file > select 3FAP from both Sequence and Name panels > give a name (3FAP_complex.pdb)

title: Molecular Docking Analysis
text:
3.1 Splitting the complex

Split receptor and ligand:

From the right-side panel, right click on 3FAP > split > Split at selected molecules > select the ligand (second A in the sequence panel)
Now you can see two objects in the right-hand panel: receptor and ligand

Rename the objects:

Right click on the receptor object > Name > enter ‚ÄúReceptor‚Äù
Right click on the ligand object > Name > enter ‚ÄúLigand‚Äù

title: Molecular Docking Analysis
text:
3.2 Saving individual components

Save the receptor:

File > Save as > PDB file > select Receptor > OK > give a name (3FAP_receptor.pdb)

Save the ligand:

File > Save as > Other file format > select Ligand from the Object panel > find sdf-MDL Mol from the Format panel > enter a name (3FAP_ligand) > OK


At this point, you should have three files in your working directory: - 3FAP_complex.pdb - 3FAP_receptor.pdb - 3FAP_ligand.sdf

title: Molecular Docking Analysis
text:
4.1 Defining the simulation cell

Generate the simulation cell:

From the right-hand panel, right-click on Ligand object > Select > newly
Then Simulation > Define simulation cell > around selected atoms

Remove the ligand:

Right-click on the Ligand object > Delete

Save the receptor + simulation cell:

File > Save as > YASARA Scene > give a name (3FAP_receptor.sce)

title: Molecular Docking Analysis
text:
4.2 Running the docking simulation

Set up docking:

Options > Macro & Movie > set target > select 3FAP_receptor.sce > select ‚Äòfrom underscore‚Äô > OK

Run docking:

Options > Macro & Movie > Play macro > find and click on dock_run.mcr > OK

title: Molecular Docking Analysis
text:
5.1 Binding energy analysis

Analyze the results:

Check for the log file (3FAP.log) in the working directory
Look at the binding energy values in the first table (Bind.energy)
The first entry always has the best binding energy value

title: Molecular Docking Analysis
text:
5.2 Visual inspection of docking poses

Open predicted and crystal structures:

Open the best predicted binding pose (3FAP_001.yob) by YASARA (drag and drop)
Open the crystal structure of the ligand (3FAP_ligand.sdf) (drag and drop)

Optimize visualization:

View > Hide atoms > Aliphatic hydrogens
View > Style atoms > Stick > ALL
View > Hide atoms > Molecule > A (first entry in the Sequence panel)
View > Hide atoms > Molecule > A (second entry in the Sequence panel)

Visual comparison:

Visually inspect how well the crystal pose and the predicted docking pose overlap
Note any significant differences between the two poses

title: Molecular Docking Analysis
text:
5.3 Quantitative assessment

Calculate RMSD from crystal pose:

Analyze > RMSD of > Molecules > docked ligand (second A in the Sequence panel) > OK > crystal ligand (third A in the Sequence panel) > OK > select Molecule > OK
The RMSD value will be displayed in the panel below the screen








Success Criteria



Usually, RMSD < 2.0 √Ö is considered as a successful docking simulation.

title: Molecular Dynamics Simulation Analysis
text:
In this practical, we will analyze the results of molecular dynamics (MD) simulations to understand the impact of molecular glue on protein complex stability. Two separate MD simulations have been conducted (~30 ns each): one with the molecular glue (rapamycin) and one without it. MD simulations can reveal how the molecular glue affects the dynamic behavior and stability of the FKBP12/FRB protein complex over time.
The key metric we will focus on is the Root Mean Square Deviation (RMSD) of the protein backbone, which indicates conformational changes compared to the initial structure. Lower RMSD values suggest higher structural stability.






Learning Objectives



By the end you should be able to:

Analyze MD simulation trajectories using YASARA
Calculate and interpret RMSD values over time
Compare protein stability with and without molecular glue
Generate and interpret time-series plots of structural parameters
Draw conclusions about molecular glue effects on protein complex dynamics

title: Molecular Dynamics Simulation Analysis
text:
2.1 Setting up the analysis environment

Set the working directory:

Open YASARA
Set the working directory to your/path/MD/with_glue

Set the target:

Options > Macro & Movies > Set target > 3FAP_complex.sce

title: Molecular Dynamics Simulation Analysis
text:
2.2 Running the analysis

Execute MD analysis:

Options > Macro & Movies > play macro > md_analyze.mcr > OK








Analysis time



This analysis takes some time to complete. The macro will process the entire trajectory and calculate various structural parameters.

title: Molecular Dynamics Simulation Analysis
text:
2.3 Interpreting the results

Review the HTML report:

After analysis is complete, results will be shown in an HTML file
The report contains different analysis metrics with explanations
Focus on ‚ÄúSolute RMSD from the starting structure‚Äù for protein backbone (RMSDBb)

Understanding RMSD:

RMSDBb indicates the protein‚Äôs conformational deviation compared to the initial structure over time
Raw data is available in 3FAP_complex_analysis.tab

title: Molecular Dynamics Simulation Analysis
text:
3.1 Extracting data

Download the analysis file:

Download 3FAP_complex_analysis.tab to your local computer (using WinSCP or similar)

Open in spreadsheet software:

Open the file using MS Excel or similar software
Locate the RMSDBb column and time column

title: Molecular Dynamics Simulation Analysis
text:
3.2 Creating time-series plots

Plot RMSD vs time:

Create a scatter plot or line graph with:

X-axis: Time (ns)
Y-axis: RMSDBb (√Ö)

This shows how structural stability changes over the simulation

Calculate average RMSD:

Calculate the average RMSD over the second half of the simulation (t > 15ns)
This represents the equilibrated state of the system
Record this value for comparison

title: Molecular Dynamics Simulation Analysis
text:
4.1 Repeat analysis for control system

Set new working directory:

Change working directory to MD/without_glue

Repeat steps 2-9:

Set target to the complex without glue
Run md_analyze.mcr
Download and process the analysis results
Plot RMSD vs time
Calculate average RMSD for t > 15ns

title: Molecular Dynamics Simulation Analysis
text:
5.1 Generating comparison plots

Create comparative visualization:

Plot both RMSD curves on a single graph:

Line 1: With molecular glue (rapamycin)
Line 2: Without molecular glue

Use different colors/styles to distinguish the lines
Include proper labels and legend

title: Molecular Dynamics Simulation Analysis
text:
5.2 Statistical comparison

Compare average RMSD values:

Compare the average RMSD values from step 9 for both systems
The lower RMSD indicates higher structural stability
Calculate the difference between the two conditions

title: Molecular Dynamics Simulation Analysis
text:
6.1 Quantitative Analysis

What are the average RMSD values for the second half of each simulation (t > 15ns)?

With molecular glue: _____ √Ö
Without molecular glue: _____ √Ö

What is the difference in average RMSD between the two conditions? What does this tell you about the effect of rapamycin?
Describe the time evolution of RMSD in both simulations. Do you see different patterns of equilibration?

title: Molecular Dynamics Simulation Analysis
text:
6.2 Structural Interpretation

How does the molecular glue affect the overall stability of the protein complex? Provide quantitative evidence.
What biological significance does this stability difference have for mTOR signaling?
Are there any periods during the simulation where the differences are most pronounced? What might this indicate?

title: Molecular Dynamics Simulation Analysis
text:
6.3 Methodological Considerations

Why do we focus on the second half of the simulation for calculating averages?
What other parameters from the MD analysis might be relevant for understanding molecular glue effects?
What are the limitations of this analysis approach? How might you improve it?

title: Molecular Dynamics Simulation Analysis
text:
7.1 Additional metrics

Hydrogen bond analysis: Count hydrogen bonds between rapamycin and the proteins over time
Contact analysis: Monitor specific residue-residue contacts
Flexibility analysis: Calculate B-factors or root mean square fluctuation (RMSF)

title: Molecular Dynamics Simulation Analysis
text:
7.2 Extended comparisons

Different time windows: Compare stability at different simulation periods
Per-residue analysis: Identify which protein regions are most affected by the molecular glue








Key Takeaways




MD simulations reveal dynamic effects of molecular glues on protein complexes
RMSD analysis provides quantitative measures of structural stability
Rapamycin stabilizes the FKBP12/FRB complex by reducing conformational fluctuations
Comparative analysis between conditions is essential for understanding molecular mechanisms
Equilibration time must be considered when analyzing MD trajectories
Visual and statistical analysis complement each other in MD interpretation

title: Molecular Dynamics Simulation Analysis
text:
7.3 Expected Outcomes
Based on the biological role of rapamycin, you should observe:

Lower RMSD values in the presence of rapamycin
More stable complex with molecular glue
Reduced conformational fluctuations when rapamycin bridges the proteins

These results support the mechanism by which rapamycin acts as a molecular glue to stabilize protein-protein interactions and modulate cellular signaling pathways.
